awd_titl_txt: Quantum Many Body Control and Metrology with an Atom-Light Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
At its core, technology is concerned with the design and control of physical systems (devices) that can perform desired tasks.  The more complex the device, the greater the likelihood that it will consist of many interconnected parts, as is the case, for example, with the hardware in a computer.  Physicists have long known that the behavior of interconnected systems will change in fundamental ways when the entire network (nodes and interconnects) is governed by the laws of quantum mechanics, and more recent work has shown that this allows for dramatic improvements in the performance of computers, communication networks, and sensors.  Building and operating quantum devices of this sort remains a grand challenge for modern science.  This project will contribute by developing a quantum interface that can connect distant quantum systems. The main goal is to use laser light, first to connect and "entangle" the quantum states of atoms confined in a "trap" made of laser light, and subsequently to perform a quantum limited measurement on them.  Ensembles of atoms are used in the most precise sensors of time (atomic clocks), of rotation and acceleration (inertial sensors), and of magnetic fields.  The principal investigator and others have demonstrated that a quantum interface can be used to suppress the intrinsic quantum uncertainty of measurement (a phenomenon known as "squeezing"), and thus to improve the precision of such atomic sensors beyond the "standard" limit. This project seeks to increase the amount of squeezing that can be generated by making optimal use of the internal structure of the atoms, with the goal of boosting measurement sensitivity by an additional order of magnitude.  A secondary goal is to explore a version of the atom-light quantum interface where the light is guided by an optical nanofiber and overlaps with atoms trapped close to its surface.  This geometry is far more compact and has the potential to operate as a quantum node in an optical fiber based network.

Quantum control on all scales, from single particles to complex many body systems, is a grand challenge for the second century of quantum mechanics. Over the past decade there has been substantial progress towards this goal, including significant advances in real-world technical capabilities. As a result, non-trivial quantum control has become routine in experiments ranging from quantum metrology to analog quantum simulation and rudimentary digital quantum computing. The goal of this project is to contribute new ideas and capabilities in the areas of quantum many body control and quantum metrology. The context is that of a Cs atomic ensemble, driven by magnetic fields and coupled to a quantized light field for the purpose of generating entanglement and performing quantum limited measurements. Two distinct versions will be studied: a "free-space" geometry with atoms in a dipole trap coupled to a paraxial probe beam, and a "nanofiber" geometry with atoms trapped and probed by evanescent fields around an optical nanofiber. The principal investigator brings expertise in internal state control of complex atoms that can significantly enhance the entangling power of the atom-light interface. A common measure of entangling power is the spin squeezing generated by quantum backaction when measuring the collective atomic spin.  A preliminary exploration indicates that squeezing can be increased from a baseline of ~3dB to as much as 8dB through optimal control of the atomic internal state, reaching a level comparable to cavity enhanced experiments. The nanofiber platform is less developed, but short-circuits some of the limitations that diffraction imposes on atom-light coupling in free space, and has the potential to be more compact, less complex, and far more robust than cavity-enhanced setups.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Accurate control of quantum systems, from single atoms to complex aggregates of millions of subsystems, is a key part of the Second Quantum Revolution and the technologies that may result. For metrology and sensor applications, a growing body of work has focused on the use of quantum entanglement to improve the performance of atomic clocks, atom interferometers, and magnetometers. That work has typically used clouds of atoms tricked into behaving as two-level systems, thereby sidestepping both the challenges and opportunities inherent to controlling the internal structure of complex, multilevel atoms. This Project has demonstrated that entanglement can be generated and sustained in a cloud of a million Cs atoms, each having a large internal spin. The atoms are probed with quantized light so that measurement backaction leads to simultaneous entanglement and squeezing of both the internal and collective atomic spins. The Project has further demonstrated that composite-pulse control, a technique commonly associated with MRI, can be deployed to manipulate the total (internal and collective) spin. Composite-pulse control is far more resilient to noise on both the applied and ambient magnetic fields, and makes it possible to drive the spin through complex rotations while keeping it at the Heisenberg uncertainty limit. The combination of composite-pulse control and quantum backaction resulted in as much as 5.5dB of spin squeezing, sufficient to improve the resolution of an atomic magnetometer by a factor of ~3.5 relative to the standard quantum limit.  These findings were in excellent quantitative agreement with a model taking into account both the relevant atomic physics and the three-dimensional configuration of atoms and light, thereby validating a considerable body of theoretical work going back more than a decade.

Building on the above, the Project carried out an initial exploration of quantum feedback, here defined as the combination of continuous quantum measurement and real-time feedback driven by classical magnetic fields. As an example, quantum feedback was used to implement and evaluate a simple scheme for closed-loop magnetometry. In a proof-of principle demonstration it was shown that closed-loop magnetometry can improve the sensitivity of an atomic magnetometer by at least 4.3dB (a factor ~2.7) relative to the so-called standard quantum limit. On a bandwidth- and volume-adjusted basis, this is a significant improvement over the closest comparable atom-based magnetometers. Further improvement will likely result from repeating the experiment in a shielded environment free of noisy background fields.

Looking beyond spin squeezing and closed-loop metrology, Project related work extended to a theoretical study of a new type of hybrid many body dynamics that can be realized through closed-loop control. The basic idea is that control need not be restricted to negative feedback. More general control laws can in principle be used to implement semi-classical versions of popular models for quantum nonlinear dynamics, whose classical counterparts exhibit deterministic chaos.  The emergence of chaos in meso-and macroscopic quantum systems is an important problem in the study of the quantum/classical transition, and has gained new salience with the realization that quantum chaos may be a significant limiting factor in analog quantum simulation and computation.

BROAD IMPACT

Graduate education has been central to all parts of the Project. It has provided support for two PhD students, one of whom has graduated with a PhD and found work in a local R&D company. Both have participated in and presented at several annual meetings of SQuInT, one of the major conferences held regularly by the US Quantum Information community. Project-related science has been featured by hosting groups of undergraduates as part of a Laboratory Immersion experience at the annual Optics and Photonic Winter School and Workshop, a University of Arizona/College of Optical Sciences outreach event seeking to motivate undergraduates to pursue a PhD in an optics-related field.  More broadly, the Project was undertaken within the context of the Center for Quantum Information and Control (CQuIC), an NSF-funded Focused Research Hub for Theoretical Physics that provides a physics-based perspective on Quantum Information Science. Through weekly group meetings and internal workshops, the research highlighted here has impacted a much broader community of students and postdocs within CQuIC, and at partner institutions such as Sandia and Los Alamos National Laboratories.
